Award.AwardTitle: Minnesota Linking Information for Kids: Creating Capacity for Data Intensive Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
The PIs of this project from the University of Minnesota are expanding the capacity for conducting data-intensive interdisciplinary research to advance knowledge and understanding of child well-being across multiple data systems including education, child welfare, health, mental health and juvenile justice. The project is integrating six additional datasets into the current Minnesota Linking information for Kids (Minn-LInK) cross-system data project. The project is building a community of researchers from diverse disciplinary communities to expand data linkage, develop infrastructure for efficient utilization of integrated data, and organize an interdisciplinary communication network. The project makes a more comprehensive set of data available to researchers, expands codebooks for new and existing data, and develops ready-to-use datasets and tools for efficient utilization. A Fellowship program to train graduate students and develop future researchers coordinates the efforts of university faculty and state agency staff.

The construction of the Minn-LInK Fellows has the potential to integrate the university into the work of the state, regional and local agencies. The collaborative training experiences for the graduate students who will be a part of the Fellows program brings together the research and disciplinary knowledge of the faculty with the agencies' experiences, understanding of the datasets, and knowledge of the policy and practical issues that are faced by the state. The collaborative community in this proposal starts from the perspective of early childhood education rather than from a K-12 or postsecondary perspective. The research infrastructure that is developed by this project expands the capacity of researchers throughout the state of Minnesota to better use the longitudinal integrated data to more fully understand the influence of student performances in STEM on multiple malleable factors in education.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
Child well-being is complex and spans multiple disciplines and systems. Despite efforts of government policies and programs, interdisciplinary collaboration continues to be limited in child-serving, social service fields. Incompatible data systems, ineffective communication, and lack of clear understanding of policies and guidelines across various disciplines are some of the major problems experienced. The result is that our systems remain fragmented, limiting our ability to effectively support children and families.

The Minnesota Linking Information for Kids: Creating Capacity for Data-Intensive Research project utilized a data-intensive, interdisciplinary approach to reduce some of the barriers associated with the disconnected nature of government systems in the study of child well-being. The project expanded the capacity for conducting data-intensive interdisciplinary research using integrated, statewide administrative datasets to advance knowledge and understanding of child well-being across multiple systems (including education, child welfare, health, mental health, juvenile justice). Through the project, a community of scholars from diverse disciplines came together to efficiently utilize the linked, cross-system administrative data to inform service delivery and policy development.

This projected addressed some of inherent issues by expanding cross-systems data linkages, developing infrastructure for efficient utilization of integrated data, and organizing a community of researchers to efficiently utilize integrated data, while promoting data-intensive interdisciplinary research, increasing interdisciplinary communication, and enhancing collaborative service provision. The project expanded infrastructure with a new, interactive codebook and other support materials to assist researchers in understanding the data, as well as the creation of a data key to reduce the time-intensive process of matching data across multiple systems. New datasets were acquired to increase our understanding of child well-being, enhancing the knowledge base in the practice and policy community.

In addition, this project organized a community of researchers by training future researchers (via the Minn-LInK Doctoral Fellowship Program) and increased collaborations among service providers, administrators, and policy makers. Dissemination of Fellows’ research resulted in four dissertations, five Minn-LInK briefs, five local and national conference presentations, and six peer-reviewed publications (manuscripts currently in preparation or under review). Collaborative partnerships in the practice and policy community have been strengthened through increased meetings and consultations, information sharing, and new research projects across a variety of disciplines related to child well-being. All materials developed through the Minn-LInK Collaborative Research Network  (e.g., project reports, project summaries, briefs, etc.) have been, and will continue to be, made available on the Minn-LInK website for use by others, such as students, policy makers, practitioners, and other special interest groups.  

 


Last Modified: 12/19/2016
Modified by: Kristine N Piescher
